The proceedings of the Grand Jury are questionable enough to arouse extreme suspicion. The reluctant prosecutor claimed that all relevant evidence was presented to the jurors. But none of it was subject to cross-examination, which did not stop McCulloch after the event from portraying some witnesses as reliable and others not.

Having heard Wilson's own words in a TV interview, it's hard to believe he wasn't coached in what to tell the Grand Jury. Not lacking weight and stature himself, his portrayal of himself as threatened "a 5-year-old holding onto Hulk Hogan" or being confronted by a "demon" come over as risible comic-book stereotypes.

Justice may or may not have been done, but it certainly was not seen to be done. Which is why, at the very least, Wilson should have had to face a criminal trial. There are without doubt times when police have to use deadly force, while many officers go through an entire career without firing their weapon in earnest. Wilson may have used it as a first, not a last, resort, and he should have been held to account.

If not being the Eddie Haskell type; being tall, large and confident, being a teenager without a fully developed adult brain, is not something that police officers are trained to take into account, in an effort to de-escalate a situation or confrontation, IT SHOULD BE! You say that "while he 'could' have backed off early in the confrontation, he was in fact doing his job". Well, that is just a silly statement. His job is being a police officer. He was in his car, in uniform, carrying legal weapons, on duty, etc. We can all agree that he was doing his job. The issue is how he was carrying out his job duties, at that time.

Secondly, councilor, was he still doing his job (or as he states, "following procedure)", when he washed the blood off of his hands and did not write an immediate detailed report on the incident, AFTER he had killed this unarmed teenaged, scary acting, bigger, demon, who had just punched him so darned hard that his face actually had a couple of reddened areas? Was it just his job, when he added the mysterious, "he reached for his waist", months later? As an attorney, you are well aware that these are issues that any reasonably competent attorney would cross examine him on; but we will never know how the story he told would hold up under cross, now will we?

The last thing you would do after a shooting would be to write a report. You have just taken a human life. You are a human being, not a robot. You go to the hospital and you get counseled and evaluated. You do not give up your constitutional rights just because you are a police officer.

Wilson's job was to correct a potentially dangerous situation e.g. two men walking in traffic. This situation was dangerous not only to drivers but to the men themselves. Brown decided to escalate it.

Regardless of whether or not Wilson knew Brown was the thug in the convenience store, we all now know that Brown was large, powerful and had an attitude problem. Like it or not, cops are not required to duke it out before taking other defensive measures. YMMV.

I have grown weary of the steady drumbeat of officer-involved-shootings. However, as a retired lawyer familiar with the weapon use laws in my home state, I often wonder where an aggressive physical confrontation turns potentially deadly, allowing an armed citizen (or cop) to legally defend him/herself against an unarmed but larger, more powerful aggressor.

In other words, does a person have to be killed or seriously injured before we, in hindsight, conclude that said person would have been legally-entitled to use deadly force in self-defense?

Americans come in all sizes and shapes, and some are pretty scary even when young. While Mr. Brown was a teenager, he was not an Eddie Haskell wimp teenager. He was tall, large and confident. We all know teenage brains are not fully developed, and their appreciation of consequences is limited, but that does not mean society has to let them have their way in all situations.

While Officer Wilson could have backed off early in the encounter, he was in fact doing his job. Mr. Brown decided to escalate the situation rapidly, and with the knowledge that he was playing with fire.

PS: in my hometown, stupid white guys get shot by white cops every year. Hard to attribute it to racism.

"If the officer does something wrong you can always file a grievance or a lawsuit later."  But you'd lose unless you had a clear video or videos to support your claim.  Until recently, victims never had video evidence, and the police would win on insufficient evidence if the victim's grievance even got to court; in most cases, lawyers wouldn't take the case because the victim would lose.
Actually, there was a good deal of marijuana in Brown's system.  Marijuana generally does not make users aggressive, but it does impair general judgment.

Not sure what Mr Brown's psychological state and judgment were at the time, it may have been impaired, not by a poor understanding of the basic police officer-citizen encounter. My own idea is this: if an officer of the law ever told me to stop or be still or back down, I would always do it. They are one of he most regulated services in the planet. Why would your reaction be to grab a police officer's gun? By doing that the situation goes from highly predictable to extremely unpredictable and dangerous. And, it is a situation where the heft of the law and the tactical advantage goes to the police officer. You are going to lose: you will either lose your life or go to jail.

People who fight with the police tend to get shot not so much by virtue of race but by virtue of their actions which disorder the basic rules of the police officer and citizen interaction: that is, in the moment, your job as a citizen is to obey the legal expert and the keeper of civil order: the police officer. If the officer does something wrong you can always file a grievance or a lawsuit later. But, better to save your life and never do anything to make the encounter chaotic and more tense.

You obviously didn't bother reading the physical evidence presented that makes the testimony of MB's friend unbelievable. His version does not correspond to the physical evidence. Therefore he fabricated. Wilson's version DOES correspond with the physical evidence. That is why his version is more believable.

There were other witnesses just as credible as Brown's friend, like white construction workers.  Besides, since there is no video of the shooting, the physical evidence is in no way definitive on exactly what happen after Wilson left the car and chased down the unarmed man.

Several of the commenters and defenders of officer Wilson take his words at face value.  I just read in this paper that a jury found a policeman in New York City responsible for a death in 2005, after he had earlier been exonerated on his testimony.  Wilson could also have shaped his four hour testimony to protect himself from a possible indictment.  Indeed, since the prosecutor McColloch showed no intent to do anything but exonerate Wilson, he got no tough questioning.  Why is his testimony more believable than Brown's friend and nearby witness not as believable as Wilson's? And other witnesses cast doubt on his version of events.  Indeed, several very smart journalists who have looked at the transcripts of his testimony find his description of what took place hard to believe.  In any case, a real trial with a real prosecutor might have cleared up many of the uncertainties that still remain.
